comments:
HEAD

Widget is disposed exception in TreeViewer => Package Explorer unusable.

Steps:
- org.eclipse.core.expressions from CVS
- create new package p
- drag all *.java files from package org.eclipse.core.expressions to p
- click OK

=> Log fills up with the Exceptions below

The change in TreeViewer 1.92 (bug 209097) looks very suspicious. The exceptions don't happen with 1.91.

My guess would be that we do not update the element map when calling removeAll.

The problem here is that the tree path code does not protect against disposed
items - this is a general tree viewer problem that we should address.

We can fix it in the specific code by adding an unmapAllElements - however this
doesn't play nice with a tree like the package explorer as it causes a loss of
context with an unneccessary collapse.

I am going to leave the api in as it is a good idea in general but I think it
is something we are going to need to optimize on a case by case basis rather
than be able to get an improvement everywhere.

I'll still use this algorithm in the viewers that aren't as deep (like the
markers view but we need to watch out for the loss of context issue in other
viewers).

I have pushed the optimization down in HEAD to the MarkersTreeViewer. We should either rename this bug to capture the problem with tree paths and removed widgets or close it as fixed and open a new one.
*** Bug 209967 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Reducing the priority as we have fixed the exception in HEAD

(In reply to comment #2)
> The problem here is that the tree path code does not protect against disposed
> items - this is a general tree viewer problem that we should address.

The tree path code assumes that the element map and the items' data are consistent with each other. By calling removeAll without deleting the associated entries from the element map, we end up with pointers to disposed items in the element map, which later on leads to widget disposed exceptions.

We should not change the tree path code to protect against disposed items because that would mask the root problem and make it harder to debug.

The problem is that the tree viewer is supposed to allow for Tree operations to be called if there is no equivalent TreeViewer operation.

If this is the case we need a removeAll(Object) for the TreeViewer.
remove(Object,index) is actually likely suffecient. All I would change is to mention in the API that this should be used instead of removeAll

Viewers are not designed to allow calls to the underlying tree or table that make structural changes. We can still put the optimization in, it's just not that easy because we have to make sure that the element map is updated correctly.
